bibl.title: Speech: X Marks the Spot, by [Philip Showalter Hench], January 20, 1955

div1.p: [Hench] discusses his experiences in visiting sites where outstanding medical developments took place or where famous individuals lived or are buried. He includes an account of the yellow fever experiments. The speech was given at the New Fellows Banquet at the Mayo Foundation House.

div1.head: Speech: X Marks the Spot, by [Philip Showalter Hench], January 20, 1955
div1.p: “X” MARKS THE SPOT*

After-Dinner Talk; New Fellows Banquet
Mayo Foundation House, January 20, 1955

Man is a forward-moving creature with a backward-looking mind.
For inspiration to solve the problems of today he often turns to dramatic
events of the past. Thus he may search the face of the earth until that
exciting moment when he can stop, and with the thrill of rediscovery, ex-
claim: “This is the place. This is the very spot. Here is where it happened.”

On my wanderings I have always enjoyed trying to find the exact
locations where some outstanding medical development took place. Some such
are far from the main path; others are just around a nearby, but forgotten,
corner. Sometimes a modest memorial identifies the place. But more often,
not even an “X” on a local map marks the spot.

X In the time (30 min.) allowed me, let me take you to a few of these
places. The island of Michilimacinac is a lovely vacation spot. Mackinac,
as we know it, is famous for its “hotel with the longest porch in the world.”
X ...and for its old fort built in 1780.
X From the fort we can see the town below, and the house where, in 1822, a
young 19 year-old French Canadian was accidentally shot in the stomach.
X It happened in the cellar of this house.
X Within minutes, he was being cared for by a 36-year old Army doctor, the post
surgeon, who moved the wounded man to this little one-story hospital at the
fort. Here the army physician, Dr. William Beaumont, took care of the “alto-
gether helpless” Alexis St. Martin for a year.

X When the county would no longer be financially responsible for the
invalid, (whom they named “a common pauper”) Dr. Beaumont, a family man with
a salary of only $40 a month, took him into his own family-quarters and cared
for him for 2 more years, solely as a patient, and not as a subject for ex-
perimentation, for this idea did not strike Beaumont until later, after the
failure of all his attempts to close the wound, which had left an opening into the
stomach.

X Far from any medical center, Beaumont began to make scientific history. He
had practically nothing to use except two things, but both of them were rare and in-
valuable - a human stomach with a hole in it, and the one fine instrument at his com-
mand - his own clear, imaginative brain.

X His observations on the physiology of the human stomach made him “the
pioneering American physiologist.” After 75 years of neglect, this birthplace of
American physiology was finally memorialized in 1900.

X If you've been to Brussels, Belgium, you have admired this magnificent old
square...
X and seen this whimsical figure of the Manekin-pis.
X But have you visited the shooting gallery of the Belgian Army on the outskirts of
town?

X Let's walk to the targets in the rear. During an October night 39 years ago,
German soldiers lined up where my friend is standing. ago, AA frail 50-year old woman was led out. Facing the soldiers. she stood erect on
the precise spot from which I took this photograph a few weeks ago.

X In the darkness, at 2 a.m., the German soldiers fired one volley, and here
an English nurse who had been working in a hospital run by Dr. Depage, the father of
a Mayo Foundation Fellow, fell dead. She was Nurse Cavell who, a few hours earlier,
had told a prison chaplain: “Patriotism is not enough.” Her executioners put her
body in the high field in the background (here), and there it lay for 4 years. Then
lovingly the Belgians and British gathered her up to be honored amongst the kings
and nobles of Empire in Westminster Abbey, before they laid her to rest in Norwich
Cathedral.

X Here just off Trafalgar Square in London is her monument, with an inscrip-
tion of majestic simplicity: “Edith Cavell - Brussels - Dawn - Oct. 15, 1915.”

X Now that we're in London, let's take a short train ride. We are in Oxford
and the bicycles suggest that a busy university session is on.

X Let us hunt up #13 Norham Gardens, a lovely old house even on a rainy day.
When I was there, it was a glorified rooming house for young ladies. Outside the house
there is no mark of distinction, but the young ladies fortunate enough to live there,
feel the presence of its former master, the Professor of Medicine who lived here from
1907 until his death in 1919.

X A warm, lived-in house, autumn leaves and the plucky remains of an English
garden; for 12 years the international mecca of physicians, medical students and es-
pecially young medical officers during World War I. For here they experienced the
glowing hospitality of their incomparable hosts, Sir William and Lady Osler.

X One of our Foundation Fellows calls this lovely place home - The Lake of Thun,
near Interlaken, Switzerland.
X After watching several suns rise and set on the Jungfrau...
X ...while resting a few days at Wengen last year.....
X....I drove Mrs. Hench along the length of Brienersee and down the valley of the Aare
River...
X ...to this little Swiss town of Meiringen. I wanted to explore the place where a de-
plorable accident occurred 64 years ago, one that caused dismay and sorrow throughout
the civilized world (and I use advisedly the term “civilized world”). On the after-
noon of May 4, 1891, two men left the Englischer Hof at Meiringen and set out on a
short walking tour. One was a 39 year old London physician, a graduate of London University and of St. Bart's; his companion,, a
37 year old alumnus of Oxford was, among other things, a first-class chemist and something of an genius.

X They passed the base of Hasleberg (on the left) and crossed over the narrow
Aare River to the little village of Willigen, at the foot of the mountain on the right.

X Then they started to climb leisurely to this summit, planning to pause on
the way, to view the top of the waterfall you see here.

X We are now about halfway up this winding road which leads from Willigen
below us, to the hamlet of Rosenlaui from which height there are magnificent vistas.

X I found, as I followed their footsteps, that the slope of the road was
deceptive, the grade being steeper than it looked.

X Therefore I suspect that they welcomed, as I did, a chance to interrupt
their upward climb when they reached this by-path, a small detour which took them,
after about 1/2 mile or so, to the top of the falls we saw previously from below.

X But before it reaches the brink of the main falls, the path, sloping down
through a rocky and heavily wooded region, brings one to this charming little cascade,
a tiny oasis of sparkling sunlight amidst the dark forest. It occurred to me that,
just as the water, falling gently here, is unaware of the awesome drop just ahead of
it, the two vacationing Britishers on passing this peaceful spot never dreamed that
brutal, tragic death was only minutes away.

X Almost immediately beyond this cascade the earth drops suddenly away and
the water, which even in summer is cold from the melting snow, plunges into this
tremendous abyss from which the spray rolls up like the smoke from a burning house.

X It is indeed a fearsome place, a precarious spot where I was glad for my
borrowed alpen-stock.

X The shaft into which the water hurls itself is, as you can see, an immense
chasm, lined by glistening, coal-black rock, and narrowing into a creaming, boiling
pit of incalculable depth, which brims over and shoots the stream onward over its
jagged lip. In 1891, as now, the path had been cut half-way round the fall to afford
a complete view.

Just as the two men rested for the view, a young Swiss boy came running,
short-of-breath, with a message from the Meiringen innkeeper imploring the physician
to return at once to care for an emergency, an English guest with a severe hemorrhage.
Reluctantly he agreed to do so, promising to join his companion that evening to spend
the night at Rosenlaui.

But the distinguished chemist never reached Rosenlaui and when the physician
and police-experts returned to the falls they found the unmistakable footprints of
the British scientist and those of a stranger, also signs of a desperate struggle on
the slippery edge of the narrow, spray-drenched path and finally one or two personal
belongings - that was all!

X According to a short account in a Geneva newspaper, the bodies of the two
victims of this mysterious encounter must have plunged deep into this foaming water,
only part of which falls over the rim, for the rest of it drains off, so I was told
by a local resident, through a rock-bound subterranean passageswhich emerges far down
the slope. At any rate, the bodies were never found.

X If their frightened eyes were open as they fell through space, this is what
they saw in their last moments of agony: the town of Willigen in the foreground,
Meiringen beyond and the narrow river Aare between.

Because of what this unique figure meant to the world, his involvement in
this tragic and mysterious affair stunned his generation.

X Three years later in London, England, there was a singular epilogue to
this tragedy. In the year 1894 the physician was approached at night by a white-
haired old man who had information concerning his friend's fate. The old man lived
in one of the houses in this photo which I took a few weeks ago. This is a York street
corner. To clear up matters, the latter took the physician on tous walk from
Cavendish Square through alleys and back streets to Manchester Street and Blandford
Street, through a network of mews and stables until they came to this narrow street...
X and turned here into York Mews (now renamed - David Mews).
X In those days this was a deserted yard entered by a wooden gate.
X The puzzled physician followed, as his nocturnal companion used a key to enter the
rear of this house. It was empty and pitch dark. They felt their way along the cor-
ridor to the front room, and through a dirty window (which was here), looked out into
this street. What happened then sounds almost like a detective story; as the two
men waited in absolute silence, a 3rd man sneaked in with a powerful, noiseless
air-gun. He aimed it at the figure of a man by a second floor window of the house
across the street, then fired. His immediate capture gave the British police the
solution of the 4-year old mystery of Reichenbach Falls in Switzerland.

And it will I hope, satisfy your curiosity too. For in 1896 this
building was a small deserted rooming place named Camden House.
- 6 -
X The shot broke one of these 2nd floor windows across the street from “The Empty
House.” The present street number of the latter is #118 and this is now #111. But
in 1896 it was 22IB Baker Street, London. The assailant in the Empty House that night
was Colonel Sebastian Moran; the assailant who lost his life at the Reichenbach Falls
had been a brilliant professor of mathematics at one of Britain's smaller universities
until, through some diabolical heredity, he became “the Napoleon of Crime,” “the most
dangerous and capable criminal in Europe.” The British physician was named Watson -
a Dr. John Watson who later described the almost-miraculous way in which his travelling
companion and room-mate had, at the last second, saved himself from death. For the room-mate,
a distinguished detective as well as a chemist, he was skilled at Japanese “baritsu”; otherwise Sherlock
Holmes would certainly have plunged to death with Professor Moriarty.

X And now a forlorn post-script. This, the home of the greatest genius that
England ever produced, was destroyed during the last war. And it was the only building
in the whole block which was destroyed. Surely the bomb which ruined it, came not
from the enemy in the sky, but from a sneaky agent under foot who was, no doubt, some
perverted, paranoid surviving member of the Moriartyygang.

X Last September's London paper illustrated clearly how much they still need Holmes;
he would quickly solve these outrageous “Jack, the Ripper cases.”

X Now the only inhabitant of 22IB Baker Street is this black cat. But if the
owners would only restore his old home, I think the government might persuade Holmes
to abandon his bees and his books and return from the South Downs, to act as a Senior
Consultant to Scotland Yard. In this case once more he would be looking out these 2nd
floor windows into foggy Baker Street below. Then all would be well!

After this illuminating, instructive and important digression, let me return
to the verities.

x When this now-beloved structure was finished 65 years ago (1889) some eminent
Parisians spoke of it as “useless and monstrous,” a loathesome tin contraption. But
none could disparage the views from its top.

X Here is “la Rive gauche” - the left bank of song and story. On this side
are two remarkable shrines - comparable yet very dissimilar. At each one in solemn
splendor lies the body of a “conqueror” whose name is known to all men.

X At one tomb is constant hustle and bustle: outside are taxi drivers and
souvenir post cards; inside are guards and throngs of visitors who, according to a
popular legend, are forced by cynical architectural planning to “bow their heads” before
the arrogant dead.

X Immense and massive is the black marble sarcophagus which swallows up the
frail little Corsican, as if to protect him from his perennial public. Nearby are
carved the names of 12 battles won.

Also nearby are the tombs of two favored military friends: they would be
little visited except for their satellite-distinction here.

X There are bright pages in the record: Napoleonic law, Napoleonic justice,
even a short Napoleonic peace. But rightly or wrongly he is better known (to me, at
least) as a conqueror of the lands of others, a conqueror of other men. If his death-
house contains a private chapel or symbols of the cross, I missed them. If this
splendiferous rotunda invites grateful prayers of thanks for the dead, I did not
sense it.

X In a quieter street not far away, is the other shrine, but a completely
different atmosphere prevails. There are no crowds and few if any visitors on an
ordinary day. No “X” marks this spot; no sign reads: “This way to the tomb.”

X But a concierge will take you to a side door of the main building and
reverently open the crypt.

X Walk in and you find yourself, not held at awesome distance from this
tomb, but allowed to go close, as to the grave of a friend.

Here too the tomb is of marble, but it seems to be soft and colorful, dividing
but not separating the thankful living from the honored dead. As at the other tomb,
here too around the walls are inscribed the names of battlesvictories won, but these were battles
in which everybody won, and which will never have to be fought again: battles against
- 8 -
false theories, bacteria, anthrax, rabies and other diseases. Without fear, stand
close to the tomb of Louis Pasteur who discovered and conquered in the “world of the
infinitely small.” Think on this thing, and the room breathes, not of death but of
life and health for us and those who come after.

X Like Napoleon, Pasteur has two worthy comrades lying nearby. A few feet
away, from him, before a small altar, lies Madam Pasteur. And just outside, among
these flowers, lies his eminent disciple, Dr. Emile Roux.

X Nearby is the famous statue of Jupille, the second young French boy with
rabies whose life was saved by Pasteur.

X Leaving the Pasteur Institute, we pause before the figure of him whom
Osler and others called “the most perfect man who has ever entered the Kingdom of
Science.”

X Before we leave Paris let's cross the Seine to find a different kind of
shrine, an artistic one which I shall call “para-medical.” It is not far from Sacre
Coeur which you see on the horizon.

X “Everyone” visits Montmartre with its steep little streets, picturesque
passages and “art colonies.”

X Nearby is the Place du Tertre (the place of the small hill, or mound),
beloved of tourists and artists, a scene painted more often than almost any other
in Paris.

X From Montmartre most taxis, returning to downtown Paris, take one by way
of the bridge which carries the rushing traffic of the Rue Caulaincourt over the eastern
corner of the old Montmartre Cemetery. Let's dismiss our taxi on the lower end of the
bridge just above the last “avenue” in the cemetery below us, for the particular grave
we are seeking is here. Inside the cemetery-entrance we immediately turn to the left,
down the first passage.

Although we are now only a few yards from the noisy traffic above us, sud-
denly all is very still and we have the whole place to ourselves, for this cemetery
is too old for it to “know” anybody" alive today.

X Only 125 steps away we find the place we are looking for. No special “X”
marks this spot. The young woman who rests here is remembered in song and story every
year all over the world. (Indeed on this New Year's night, January 1, 1955, the ABC
devoted three hours to broadcast it again.) You and I have, more than once, shed an
artistic tear to her memory. Nevertheless hers is a pitiful, crowded privacy in this
real estate of the dead.

The name carved on each side of her tomb may stir no memories or give you no
sense of recognition. But under another name she will be remembered for many a century.
Although she died 107 years ago, the urn on top has not been too long empty of flowers
and on the sides, lovers have pencilled hearts with their initials inside.

The young tuberculous girl who has been the object of this unusual devotion lived only
23 years, the first 20 of them as an obscure peasant in Nouant. The last three years
she lived in Paris and she must have really been “something,” for during that short
time her charm, wit, regal manner and delicate beauty brought to her feet the kind of
Paris she craved. In life loved by many, indeed too many, at the end of it she died
almost alone, ravaged by consumption.
X A colorful porcelain pillow carries the word “Regrets.”

X Of the 4 other floral decorations, 3 are artificial and the only real one
(here) is fading away. Strangely symbolic, for so it was with her loves - 3 “artificial”
and one legalized one which soon died. She was the love of a French count whowhom she married
and left, inner, and of (at least) 3 great men - Dumas the elder, Dumas the younger, and
Franz Liszt. Another genius immortalized her in music which has been proudly sung by
the greatest prima donnas, including one soprano who was so well-nourished and fat that
her incongruous operatic-death from TB made the audience howl.

X For the sake of glamor this Normandy peasant girl called herself Marie
Alphonsine du Plessis, a name which didn't survive long enough to be carved on her
tomb; and no wonder, for death has a habit of stripping us of our embellishments (at
least for awhile).

But her other names have been carved on the pages of dramatic and musical
history, for she was Dumas' Marguerite Gautier, Camille or the Lady of the Camelias,
and Guiseppe Verdis' Violetta Valery or the “Lost One.” Her delicate tuberculous
- 10 -
coughing, if not always musical, has been heard round the world. So much for the
case history of La Traviata.

X Sunning herself on the 23rd parallel, Cuba looks most attractive to the
American tourist. His first close-ups include photogenic Morro Castle on the left...
X ...and the City Hall on the right.
X If he can afford it, he stays at the Hotel Nacional...
X ...and from his window he has this beautiful (but expensive) view of the Malecon drive.
X Later he shops in the Parque Central, then walks along the Prado (here)...
X ...a lovely, marble-paved promenade under cooling trees.
X Worn out by such exertions he returns to the Hotel Nacional's pool where he can
either swim...
X ...or relax with Dr. Tom Spies as a delightful companion...
X ...or just relax! (What am I saying!) (Photo of Donna Osterberg)

X Then a night-boat takes the usual tourist back home, with his memories of
Sloppy Joe's, Cuban rum and jai alai, and his photos of Central Park, the Prado,
Plaza des Armas, the Casino, Yacht Club and La Playa.

But an informed physician can see much more, for these and nearby places
were the locale for one of the most exciting medical adventures of all time.

X It reached its climax in this tumble-down, forgotten little shack which I
helped to find in 1939.

X Later, because of its historic importance, the Cuban Government declared it
to be a “national monument,” restored it and created a little park around it. Finally
on December 3, 1952, they raised over it the Cuban flag and dedicated it as a memorial
to the conquerors of yellow fever.

X Let's begin the story 75 years ago when this terrible disease annually spread
like a plague from Cuba to the U.S. at a cost of millions of dollars and thousands of
lives each year. In 1879 an American commission went to Havana; later its report con-
tained everything about yellow fever, everything, that is except its cause. In terms
- 11 -
of immediate value the Chaille report was quite useless, but indirectly it was price-
less for it disturbed the thinking of a distinguished Cuban physician living here at
#52 on the Prado.

X Abandoning his own 21 year-old theory, Dr. Carlos Finlay accepted the
American Commission's opinion that “the poison of yellow fever was a living organism”
of unknown nature and source. Then, by an epoch-making cerebration which he modestly
spoke of as “simple reasoning” he excluded thousands of germs and insects, and in 1881
announced his opinion that a culex mosquito was the carrier of yellow fever. To prove
it he inoculated over 100 unquarantined volunteers, but the few who got sick were believed by others
to have developed their disease naturally, not experimentally. And so, after 19 years
of work and 59 papers thereon, he had only one convert, his assistant, Delgado.

X In 1900 General Leonard Wood was Governor of Cuba and in command of the thousands
of American soldiers there. His old headquarters is now the City Hall. When the
epidemic of yellow fever developed that spring many of his staff who lived in this
building just across the Plaza des Armas (The Segundo Cabo, now the Supreme Court
Building) took sick and died.

X About 6 miles away in his headquarters at suburban Quemados de Marianao.
General Lee and his medical officers worried over the safety of the American troops
most of whom were stationed at nearby Columbia Barracks.

X They didn't have long to wait, for in May yellow fever killed a soldier
living here at 102 Calzada Real (still same number), then struck at this house around
the corner, at 20 (now 404) Gen. Lee Street.

X At the Post Hospital was Jesse W. Lazear, a young Army contract-doctor.
Having studied malaria, he respected Finlay's notions about mosquitos and yellow fever.
So he captured some mosquitos in one of these houses and sought vainly for a parasite.

X As the epidemic spread the Surgeon General appointed an Army Yellow Fever
Board: Reed and Carroll from Washington joined Agramonte and Lazear at the Post Hos-
pital in Quemados, which was, in 1900, exactly here, where now stands the Cuban Army
hospital at what is still called Camp Columbia, only a mile from the bathing
beach, LaPlaya.

X Unable to isolate a yellow fever germ they turned to Finlay's old theory,
and got some mosquito larvae from Dr. Finlay who by then had moved from the Prado to
this place at 110 (now 460) Aguacate Street.

X While Reed was temporarily recalled to Washington, Lazear at Camp Columbia
made nine unsuccessful, then suddenly two successful inoculations. A few days later
Lazear himself developed severe yellow fever and died of what we now know was almost
certainly secret, self-induced yellow fever. They buried him near here, in a little
temporary army cemetery near the post hospital.

X Returned to Havana, Reed studied Lazear's notes on the timing of the suc-
cessful and unsuccessful inoculations and discovered why the experiments of Finlay and
the first ones of Lazear had been negative or inconclusive. But the Board's first re-
port was received with indifference or ridicule because these first American volunteers
were not under strict quarantine.

X So Reed visited General Wood in this room in the present City Hall...
X ...and got permission to establish in Quemados an experimental station named “Camp
Lazear.”

X In Quemados, on Calzada Real was (and still is) the Finca San Jose, a small
estate and farm owned by a Cuban, Dr. Rojas.

X Behind this lovely old house where his daughter now lives was an open field which suited Major Reed's
purposes.

X Seven tents and two special buildings were set up under strict quarantine. In Building #1 (and
this is the way it looked when we found it in 1940) brave volunteers slept on sheets
and pillows and in clothing terribly soiled by yellow fever patients. But none de-
veloped yellow fever because there were no mosquitos. Here are the tongued and grooved
boards, the flattened ceiling and the stove-pipe hole so carefully described by Reed,
features quite unknown to Cuban construction.

X Eighty yards in front of Building #1 was Building #2 where my friend
Doctor Nogueira stands. It blew down in 1926. but Johnny Moran and I found fragments of its flooring. In it Johnny Moran (O'Hara" in “Yellow
Jack,” the TV play of ten days ago) was exposed to infected mosquitos and promptly
developed yellow fever.

Other experiments here clinched matters, gave to Reed and his associates
enough proof, and laid the foundation for the elimination of yellow fever from most
of the world.

X As an aftermath of my snooping, I flew to Havana two years ago, a guest of
the Cuban Government to help dedicate “The Camp Lazear Memorial Park.” Invited also
were the families of Reed, Lazear and all others who had helped.

X Present were the diplomatic corps, cabinet members and many others and
among them the families of Finlay and Delgado.

X Bronze tablets and profiles were unveiled and decorated with flowers.
X That of Dr. Agramonte was unveiled by his daughter.

X Of the 25 principal men whose hopes were fulfilled at Camp Lazear 3 were
Cubans, 4 were Spaniards, one was English, one Irish and 16 American. They included
the humble and the privileged, civilians and soldiers, professionals and volunteers,
Catholics, Protestants and Jews. And here where the Cuban flag now flies in their
honor, they afforded a supreme demonstration of the potential brotherhood of man.

Now we have visited briefly several unusual places. Does any common de-
nominator link the U. S. Army surgeon at out-of-the-way Mackinac Island in 1822
with those at even farther-away Quemados Cuba in 1900, the English nurse who died before
the firing squad in Brussels and the Professor of Medicine who lived and died at
Oxford or the bacteriologist of France. Their common
motive was, I think, an instinctive urge for humanitarian service which most of them
rendered by advancing medical knowledge.

X That was surely one of the dominant forces which motived the two men whose
honored family name we share, for the public calls us “Mayo men.” Whether we are
staff men or Foundation fellows, the right to bear that proud name carries with it
obligations which we must never forget. If we, fellows and staff, have exceptional
privileges, we have special responsibilities also, namely - to practice the art and
science of medicine with special industry, and, if possible, with special skill.

You new fellows have become an important part of the Mayo Foundation.
Indeed you are now those for whom the Foundation was created. As such, you are a very
important part of the Mayo Clinic, for largely through you, its new generation, will
the Clinic achieve its second purpose - the continuing advancement of medical science.
Consequently you of the Foundation and the members of the staff have mutual responsi-
bilities.

First, each owes the other loyal cooperation. Give to your teachers here,
to every one of them, that respect which all earnest teachers and scholars deserve.
If possible, give to your seniors here, not just your respect, but your affectionate
regard. He will treasure that “something extra” and will respond to it.

But (and this is most important) even while you give him personally your
loyalty and respect, never give him your complete trust. That is, you must not give
to his ideas your unquestioning allegiance. For if you do, you will defeat one of
the main purposes of every medical school, hospital and clinic, and the chief ob-
jective of the Mayo Foundation - namely, your chance to extend knowledge. If you
accept all his ideas and beliefs without question or constructive criticism, whether
spoken or not, you will reject the glowing philosophy of all science, that the truth
of today is only the half-truth of tomorrow.

Unlike the custom of old Europe, here we do not listen to the voice of
authority, at least not reverently. Listen closely to the voices of experience and
wisdom but not to the voice of mere authority which is always a stifling force.

If you listen to the voices of wisdom whether it be that of your elders or
preferably, that of your own growing knowledge, you may experience one of the
greatest thrills of life, the birth of a new idea, the conception of a new truth.

But it isn't enough simply to entertain a new idea. You must nourish and
strengthen it, for at first a new truth is always a precious, fragile thing, often
no more than a passing notion which can easily be killed by the slightest neglect or
ridicule. Dream about it, think about it till it eats your guts out. Then do some-
thing about it to develop and refine it. But when you start doing, you will start
- 15 -
suffering, for like that of a new human, the delivery of a new truth into the world
is a painful thing. Many times you will become discouraged. But you must never quit.

Some time ago I was reading one of Arthur Bryant's fine pieces in the London
Illustrated News. Discussing Churchill, he wrote what that immortal Englishman told
the boys of Harrow some years ago (1942). To these young men he said: “Never give in,
never, never, never, never, in nothing great or small, large or petty - never give in
except to convictions of honor and good sense...” (London I11. News, Oct. 4, 1952). Re-
member that, gentlemen, as you struggle and sweat to discover the secrets of nature,
and to make them plain to others which is, often harder to do than the first. Truth is
hard to find. She is an elusive, fickle mistress. But she is forever waiting for you
around the next corner.

And if by time and testing, you find that you have discovered a new truth,
be its humble host; meet it with humility as becomes the inquiring physician who
realizes that any single truth, no matter how impressive or useful it may be, is only
an infinitesimal fragment of what is the whole truth and nothing but the truth as
known to the Great Physician. If you so respond, then you are on your way, for your
humility will dim the glare of the new, bright truth so that you can see beyond it,

Now what is the fundamental purpose of all such laboring, of all our planning
and lecturing and demonstrating and sharing and remembering? The heart of the matter
is not just the stimulated mind (for this could produce mere cerebral self-satisfaction
or even academic snobbery). The end of it is not even the new and stimulating truth,
but the serviceable application of the truth. To be useful, medical truth must be
put to work; it must serve. A scientific truth does not, by definition, become a fact
(a noun derived from the verb, facere - “to do”) until it is made to operate.

X In the last analysis that can happen only in some such place and manner as
this, when and wherever the informed, dedicated physician and a single patient who
needs him, actually meet (photo of “The Doctor” painted by Sir Luke Fildes).

This is the place, a the sick room of whatever kind it may be, where the
truthful dreaming of the theorist, the demonstrations of the experimentalist, the
magic of the chemist, the guidance of the laboratory and the wisdom of the prac-
titioner finally come together for their critical testing. Only in the sick room can
these separate forces demonstrate their basic truthfulness and ultimate usefulness;
only here can they unite to fulfill their proper destiny which is to relieve suffering
and thus implement the will and mercy of Divine Providence.

Alone here in such a room, the physician must practice both his art and his
science. And if his prescription is fashioned well by head and heart, he too will re-
ceive satisfaction from services rendered.
